**Describe the bug**
I'm no able to save a model through content type builder after I added a JSON field with an index with "2dsphere" value (I'm using mongoose connector).

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**

1. Create a JSON field in some model through admin UI
2. Edit the `ModelName.settings.json` and add `"index":  "2dsphere"` to the previously created field
3. Restart the server
4. Try to add another field (any kind)
5. An error message should appear on screen 

**Expected behavior**
Save without problems

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Code snippets**
Here is a repo with this problem.
https://github.com/gimoteco/strapi-bug-report

**System**

- Node.js version: v12.16.3
- NPM version: 6.14.4
- Strapi version: 3.1.4
- Database: MongoDB
- Operating system: MacOS 10.15.6

**Additional context**
I tried to remove the index option and add a new index through a migration but when strapi starts it removes the previously created index.

**Describe the bug**
I have collection types with custom fields inside, as per https://strapi.io/documentation/v3.x/plugin-development/frontend-field-api.html#registering-a-new-field

When trying to make a change in the content types builder to a collection type, component, or single type with a custom field in, the model cannot be saved.

The following errors are printed in the console:

```
components[0].attributes.Icon field cannot have keys not specified in the object shape
"components[0].attributes.Icon.type must be one of the following values: media, string, text, richtext, json, enumeration, password, email, integer, biginteger, float, decimal, date, time, datetime, timestamp, boolean, component"
```

This used to work on v3.0.5 of strapi, and is broken since i updated to v3.1.4

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**

1. Create a plugin with a custom field as per https://strapi.io/documentation/v3.x/guides/registering-a-field-in-admin.html#setup
2. Add the custom field type to a collection type
3. Try to make a change in content type builder and save
4. See error

**Expected behavior**
Custom fields should be supported by content type builder, as they used to be

**System**

Node.js version: v12.18.1
NPM version: 6.14.5
Strapi version: 3.1.4
Database: postgres
Operating system: MacOS

Having over 3000 users will result in a "payload to large" error when changing permissions on the role that the users have.

1. Go to Content type builder

**Describe the bug**
Constraints on components (except required) always pass.

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**

1. Create a component `comp` with a text field `name` that have constraint `max length` to `5`.
2. Create a content-type `article` with this compo named `myCompo`, non-repeatable
3. Make request:
```
POST http://localhost:1337/articles

body: {
  myCompo: {
    name: "a name that exceeds the max length"
  }
}
```
4. See that the new entry is correctly saved and returned

**Expected behavior**
The request should respond with an error 400 instead of 200.

**System**

- Node.js version: v10.21.0
- NPM version: 6.14.4
- Strapi version: 3.1.4
- Database: SQLite
- Operating system: macOS

**Additional context**
The only constraint that works is `required` because it is set directly in the database.
You can't see this bug if you use the admin panel because some validators run in the frontend.

**Describe the bug**

In the `./extensions/documentation/documentation/vx.x.x/full_documentation.json` file, the `x-generation-date` field under `info` gets updated every time the server is restarted.  This happens even when there has been no change to the documentation or any other code in the project's codebase.

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**

1. Have a strapi server running in development mode w/ the documentation plugin installed
2. restart the strapi server, again in development mode,  with no changes made to codebase
3. observe change in `x-generation date` 

**Expected behavior**
I would expect the `x-generation-date` to only update when a change or update to documentation occurs.

**Describe the bug**

Passing callback url instead of using the default registered provider callback doesn't seems to be working. In my case I'm using SPA on many domains with one API. In this case i need the API to redirect to correct SPA instance. 

```
GET https://API.com/connect/facebook?callback=https://DOMAIN1.com/en/auth/google
GET https://API.com//connect/facebook?callback=https://DOMAIN2.com/en/auth/google
GET https://API.com//connect/facebook?callback=https://DOMAIN3.com/en/auth/google
``` 
is not working as expected 

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**

Follow tutorial on https://strapi.io/documentation/v3.x/plugins/users-permissions.html#providers part that says 

> You can also pass a custom callback url instead of using the default registered provider callback, by passing callback in the query. eg: GET /connect/facebook?callback=https://my-frontend.com/en/auth/facebook.

I was testing Google OAuth. 

**Expected behavior**

URL like http://localhost:5000/connect/google?callback=http://localhost:3001/connect/google should redirect to http://localhost:3001/connect/google after successful login. 

Seems like `callback` is not a valid name to be passed to OAuth provider and this is trimmed from actual call, so once Provider redirects back to API callback url is lost. What I have found out that `state` is a parameter that can be used here (https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/oauth2/web-server) 

> You can use this parameter for several purposes, such as directing the user to the correct resource in your application, sending nonces, and mitigating cross-site request forgery.

**Code snippets**

Changing the following code seems to be fixing the issue 
https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/master/packages/strapi-plugin-users-permissions/controllers/Auth.js#L264
```js
    // Ability to pass OAuth callback dynamically
    grantConfig[provider].callback = _.get(ctx, 'query.callback') || _.get(ctx, 'query.state') || grantConfig[provider].callback;
    grantConfig[provider].state = _.get(ctx, 'query.callback') || grantConfig[provider].callback;
```

**System**

- Node.js version: v12.16.1
- NPM version: 6.13.4
- Strapi version: 3.0.0
- Database: sqlite
- Operating system: MacOS 10.15.5

**Additional context**

I'm not creating a MR so far, because I'm not sure if my solution is valid, I'm not OAuth expert and I haven't tested any other providers except Google.

**Describe the bug**
We use the markdown editor in strapi but have some trouble with saving the styles headings and quote. If a user adds the style heading or quote to his selected text, but does nothing apart from that, the style is not saved. In the PUT request you can see the style is also not in it.
This seems to apply to styles that only put a symbol in front of the text (e.g. ## Heading 2 or > Quote).

**Steps to reproduce the behaviour**
1. Make sure you have a markdown editor in Strapi and add some text.
2. Save.
3. Return to the text, select a word and click the quote styling button (this will put a > before your selected text).

**Describe the bug** What happens is if you use more than one web process running `strapi start` and you deploy a new model and it just happens that all web processes start at roughly the same time, you end up with duplicates. Hey guys,

first of all thanks a lot for this amazing product. i really like that!

i performed the migration from 3.0.0-beta.20.3 to 3.0.1 and i ran into a problem with my node version.

the `package.json` when setting up a new project needs node to be >=10.0.0 but in fact it needs to be >= 10.10.0 in the current version of 3.0.1.

this is due to the fact, that the config in [config-loader.js](https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/master/packages/strapi/lib/core/app-configuration/config-loader.js#L13) is being parsed using `fs.readdirSync` that returns fs.Dirent[] Objects. The function `isFile` is added to node in version `10.10.0` [node docs](https://nodejs.org/api/fs.html#fs_class_fs_dirent) I had an old version of node 10 running (`10.06.3`) so `isFile` was not defined. That broke my process and i needed quiet some time to figure this out

may be you can fix this in a later version so nobody else will run into that problem.

Thanks a lot and stay healthy :)

All the best and keep on the great work!
Kai

# **Bug**
In Strapi, after deleting a **Media** Field from a **Collection-Type**, a **GET request to /upload/files** throws an **Error**.  
This should not happened.  

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**

1. Create a new Strapi App.
2. Create a **Collection-Type** with a **Media** Field.
3. Create a new **Entry** from this **Collection-Type** with a **File** uploaded.
4. Delete the **Media** Field from the **Collection-Type**.
5. Finally going to the Media Library (**GET request to /upload/files**) will result in an **ERROR**. 

**Expected behavior**
When deleting a **Media** Field from a **Collection-Type** should remove any relation between the Entries that used **Media** as a Fields and the uploaded files.

**Screenshots**
![steps](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54691546/82836210-8fa0fa80-9e9c-11ea-8d53-7aa489acdb99.jpg)


**Code snippets**
This Bug can be achieved **without** using code, this scenario **only uses the Strapi CMS**.

**System**

- Node.js version: v12.16.1.
- NPM version: 6.13.2.
- Strapi version: v3.0.0-beta.20.1
- Database: Default (SQLlite I believe).
- Operating system: Windows.

# **FIX**
I did find a "solution" to this issue.
1. Add the Media field back to the Collection-Type.
2. Remove the Media field manually from every Entry.
3. Now you can remove the Media field from the collection-type without triggering this error.

## **Possible solution**
As stated before, when deleting the Media field from the Collection-Type should remove the Media attached to every Entry that uses it.

## Describe the bug

When I want to change the **permissions** of a role, I confront an unexpected error so that it couldn't be updated: ***'entry.notFound'***

![error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20626510/78069708-caf8de80-73af-11ea-8ac3-b8398a7d1230.png)

---

I **traced** the logs and found out where the error originated in (*"node_modules/strapi-connector-mongoose/lib/queries.js"*):

![traced](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20626510/78070064-68eca900-73b0-11ea-8219-198ea2aad594.png)

So I printed the value of `params` (the input parameter of the function mentioned above):
```
{ id: "5e8338177069c5230a321064" }
```
and this value was being passed into the `findOne` function of MongoDB model.
Now it's obvious why this error occurred. It's because of the lack of this document in the MongoDB `users-permissions_role` collection:

```
{
        "_id" : ObjectId("5e8338177069c5230a321064"),
        "name" : "Authenticated",
        "description" : "Default role given to authenticated user.",
         ...
}
```

**The problem is**:

- the parameter key must be `_id`, not `id` 
- the parameter value must be `ObjectId("5e8338177069c5230a321064")`, not `"5e8338177069c5230a321064"`

because of these problems, the function `findOne` returns a null value and the error blows.

Please fix this issue :)

Both error are happening because of asynchronous SQL init calls.

```
CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS pg_trgm
duplicate key value violates unique constraint "pg_extension_name_index"
```
Happens because of multiple queries that want to accomplish creation of an extension. While first success query creates this extension ‚Äì other fails with "duplicate key".

```
error: Impossible to register the '...' model.

Happens less often, but is also the same case ‚Äì `core_storage` is created asynchronously which causes dependent queries to fail if the table is not yet created. To fix this you just need to re-run Strapi ‚Äì table `core_storage` will then be existing and other queries will succeed.

**Describe the bug**
MySQL by spec doesn't support wildcard prepend on `... MATCH ... AGAINST`. 
([Spec](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/fulltext-boolean.html), [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16720443/prepending-an-asterisk-to-a-fulltext-search-in-mysql))

Strapi prepends wildcard on every query:
https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/8d0c6848ba421680570e974e5d8606314735de3e/packages/strapi-connector-bookshelf/lib/queries.js#L768-L773

In some implementations it works, but in some (e.g. Amazon Aurora based on MySql 5.6.10a) it return empty results for any search.

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**
- Use aurora database on amazon
- Create entities 
- Search for entities in admin panel
- No results will be shown

**Expected behavior**
- Show relevant entities

**Code snippets**
```sql
#doesn't work:
select ... where MATCH(...) AGAINST('*a*' IN BOOLEAN MODE) limit 1
#works:
select ... where MATCH(...) AGAINST('a*' IN BOOLEAN MODE) limit 1
```

- NPM version:6.9.0
- Strapi version: 3.0.0-beta.18.3

- Database: mysql (MariaDB)
- Operating system: MacOS

**Describe the bug**
Relational dropdowns behavior were fine in alpha, but since beta they're pretty annoying to work with. This issue is about the annoyance because I couldn't reproduce my original issue (where I strictly couldn't get more than 21 elements in my dropdown).

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**
1. Get [this repo](https://github.com/TheRealBarenziah/strapi-reproduce-issue) (credentials are in readme)
2. There are 26 mommies (for each letter of alphabet) and a baby (which has only one mommy).
3. Before clicking on the 'babies' tab, open your browser developer tools, Network tab. Clear it.
4. Now edit the baby: we want to link it to its mom (which is 'z'). You can see the HTTP request made by the dropdown when you clicked the baby entry: `http://localhost:1337/content-manager/explorer/mommy?_limit=20&_start=0&source=content-manager`
5. Click the 'mommy' dropdown and scroll down to see it effectively fetched the 20 first mommies. As you get to the end of the dropdown, you can see the log of a new request: `http://localhost:1337/content-manager/explorer/mommy?_limit=20&_start=1&source=content-manager`
6. You still can't attribute the baby it's mom 'z', you only see moms up to 'u'
7. To find the mom 'z' you have to repeat the process of hitting the end of dropdown several times (scroll up, scroll down, scroll up, scroll down...): see how the `_start` param is incremented by 1 each time you hit the end of dropdown

**Expected behavior**
I expected a smooth experience like in alpha where the `_start` parameter were incremented by 20 each time we hit the bottom of the dropdown. My teammate work with those dropdowns a lot so he instantly noticed the change.

**Code snippets**
My workaround atm is to change [this line](https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/473d7002085eb987578ccb2b495e9c24093242c8/packages/strapi-plugin-content-manager/admin/src/components/SelectWrapper/index.js#L118) (`./node_modules/strapi-plugin-content-manager/admin/src/components/SelectWrapper/index.js` L118 )
This const:
```
  const onMenuScrollToBottom = () => {
    setState(prevState => ({ ...prevState, _start: prevState._start + 1 }));
    ref.current();
  };
```
becomes: 
```
  const onMenuScrollToBottom = () => {
    setState(prevState => ({ ...prevState, _start: prevState._start + 20 }));
    ref.current();
  };
```
Did a `yarn build` after that, and now things are better (fetching entries 20 by 20)

**System**
- Node.js version: 12.10.0
- NPM version: 6.11.3
- Strapi version: 3.0.0-beta.17.4
- Database: SQLite (same behavior with mySQL, and I assume, with all DBs)
- Operating system: Linux Mint 19.2 Tina / Amazon RedHat

**Additional context**
I can live with this issue by doing my workaround and rebuilding the app. In case anybody else is annoyed by this, the fix should do it. Basically this function is called on the event of hitting the end of dropdown. I don't like the new way of handling this (for my baby & mom example, the dropdown have to go make several requests before you're able to find 'z', and each more mommy would add another request). It's not a critical problem (the fix is easy and works well enough for me) but it deserved to be documented imo.

I'm reporting 3 issues, all related to GraphQL policies. I've also created a pull request to address these issues. Some of these issues have been reported before (will reference them), but have not been resolved.

- Node.js version: 10.15.1
- NPM version: 6.9.0
- Strapi version: 3.0.0-beta.15
- Database: Postgres
- Operating system: Mac OSX Mojave

### Issue 1: Inaccurate Documentation on GraphQL Policies
The official Strapi [documentation for using policies in GraphQL resolvers](https://strapi.io/documentation/3.0.0-beta.x/guides/graphql.html#execute-a-policy-before-a-resolver) says to use `policy: []`, but the code ([here](https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/0b822a641bff67c9386b3c4e6dc1f21b387edd20/packages/strapi-plugin-graphql/services/Mutation.js#L29) and [here](https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/0b822a641bff67c9386b3c4e6dc1f21b387edd20/packages/strapi-plugin-graphql/services/Query.js#L95)) actually searches for a `policies: []` key. 

Furthermore, REST API routes also use `policies` (and not `policy`). Even though GraphQL can have different policies per action than REST, it still doesn't make sense for these keys to be different. 

As such, documentation should be updated to instead use `policies`.

### Issue 2: Policies not triggering for custom Mutations
GraphQL Mutations policies defined in `schema.graphql`, specifically only those that link to **custom** actions inside controllers do not trigger. 

Mutations that link to shadow CRUD mutations (i.e. createPost) work just fine however.

For example:

In `api/posts/config/schema.graphql`

```
module.exports = {
  resolver: {
    Mutation: {
      customMutation: {
        policies: ["global.myCustomPolicy"], // <-- Does not trigger
        resolver: "Post.customMutation"
      },
      createPost: {
        policies: ["global.myCustomPolicy"], // <-- Triggers alright
        resolver: "Post.create"
      },
    }
  }
}
```

Related issues:
https://github.com/strapi/strapi/pull/3735 - Didn't seem to fix it.
https://github.com/strapi/strapi/issues/2766 - Predecessor to above issue
https://github.com/strapi/strapi/issues/3413

### Issue 3: Policies don't have `ctx.state.user`
Policies for **ALL** GraphQL mutations and queries (both custom and shadow crud) don't have access to `ctx.state.user`.

For example, in `config/policies/myCustomPolicy.js`
```
"use strict";

/**
 * `myCustomPolicy` policy.
 */

module.exports = async (ctx, next) => {
  console.log(ctx.state.user); // Returns undefined

  await next();
};
```

It seems that `ctx.state.user` is being populated just fine via the `permissions.js` policy in `strapi-plugin-users-permissions` [as seen here](https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/0b822a641bff67c9386b3c4e6dc1f21b387edd20/packages/strapi-plugin-users-permissions/config/policies/permissions.js#L21).

**What is the current behavior?**
Reason of error returned by Strapi is empty when webapp uses Facebook login but the user declines to share his or her email address.

This happens because parameters were inverted in file plugins/users-permissions/services/Providers.js, function getProfile:

`      // We need at least the mail.
      if (!profile.email) {
        return reject([{
          message: 'Email was not available.'
        }, null]);
      }`

"Null" should be the first param passed to reject, and the message should be the second param.

**Steps to reproduce the problem**

1. Call /connect/facebook. 
2. You will be redirected to the Facebook login page if you are not yet logged in to Facebook. Enter your Facebook username and password.
3. You will be redirected to the Facebook authorization page. Choose **not** to share your email.
4. You will be redirected to your web page with the following error: {"statusCode":400,"error":"Bad Request","message":"Bad Request"}

**What is the expected behavior?**

At step 4, Strapi should return the following error (note the reason for the error): 
{"statusCode":400,"error":"Bad Request","message":"Email was not available."}

A reason for the error is required in order to know why the login failed and to instruct the user on how to solve the problem.

It is just a matter of putting the params in the right order in the code above.

**Suggested solutions**

Replace reject call in code above with:
`return reject([null, 'Email was not available.']);`

As a side note, I would suggest the Strapi team adds a page in the doc to clarify how error handling works, so that contributors stick to the same pattern. I am confused because I see two patterns throughout the code: one with only a message (as was intended in the code above) and one with an error id, such as this example taken a few lines further down the file:

`return resolve([null, [{ messages: [{ id: 'Auth.advanced.allow_register' }] }], 'Register action is actualy not available.']);`

4. On the left side under Plugins click "Files Upload"

9. See that can no longer save changes to this Post.

I'm not sure if I'm doing anything wrong, but strapi shouldn't allow deleting the file from the "Files Upload" screen in this case, because the file is being used by another content entry. 

Ideally it should be possible to see all content entries that are referencing a file, and see files that are not referenced at all. At least through the 'Media' type fields. If can also scan for the file in WYSIWYG text fields too then would be a plus.

**What is the current behaviour?**

If I enable the "email confirmation" for new users, I receive successfully an email with a link which includes a token. That token is actually the same JWT token that I receive on the JSON payload when I register. That means that someone could register a new user with a fake email, store the JWT token received on the JSON payload and without having to open the confirmation email, inject the token in the confirmation link and the user is confirmed.



**Steps to reproduce the problem**

1. Register new user: POST /auth/local/register (with username, email, password);
2. Copy the value of the "jwt" property received in the JSON payload after executing the above request;
3. Open /auth/email-confirmation?confirmation=**paste jwt value here** ;
4. The user is confirmed without validating the email;



**What is the expected behavior?**

If there's an email confirmation, the user shouldn't be able to confirm it without actually receiving and opening an email.

**Suggested solutions**

As a quick fix (not an ideal solution) we shouldn't send the jwt token when registering if email confirmation is on.

In the **register** method of the **Auth.js** Controller, we could modify a line with the following code:

``` javascript
ctx.send({
  jwt: !settings.email_confirmation ? jwt : null,
  user: _.omit(user.toJSON ? user.toJSON() : user, ['password', 'resetPasswordToken'])

Sometimes, content types are missing in content manager.


**Steps to reproduce the problem**

This may be hard to reproduce since it is related to the order of models loaded.


**What is the expected behavior?**

**Suggested solutions**
After adding some logs to the code, I found that the problem comes from `getModels` method:
https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/eeca356060e6754c14be4baf89e317f7015264ed/packages/strapi-plugin-content-manager/admin/src/containers/SettingsPage/index.js#L40-L58

In my case, one of the content types is iterated before `plugins` and is accumulated. After that the next content type is `plugins`, so `getModels` is called recursively. After returning from recursive calls, previous accumulated value is replaced by the return value, leading to missing content type in content manager.

Concatenating the retuned result to previous accumulated value solves the problem.

This is the fix:
```
      delete: (file) => {
        return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
          // delete file on S3 bucket
          const path = file.path ? `${file.path}/` : '';
          S3.deleteObjects({
            Delete: {
              Objects: [
                {
                  Key: `${path}${file.hash}${file.ext}`
                }
              ]
            }
        }, (err, data) => {
            if (err) {
              return reject(err);
            }

            resolve();
          });
        });
      }
```

## The `IS_MONOREPO=`  && `APP_PATH=` error

### Error log:
```
üèó  Building admin...
'IS_MONOREPO' n'est pas reconnu en tant que commande interne
ou externe, un programme executable ou un fichier de commandes.
...
'APP_PATH' n'est pas reconnu en tant que commande interne
ou externe, un programme executable ou un fichier de commandes.
```

### Cause/Resolution:

#### Cause:
This issue is simply related to the way ENV vars are setted between OS's AND between shells.

We should avoid at the maximum to repose on the shell behavior, since it can hugely change between environment.

#### Resolution Proposal:
So, to achieve this, all the env changes into `package.json` scripts must be preceded with `cross-env`.

All the environment variables who need to be set for some shelljs command should be passed as command option (see: [childProcess](https://nodejs.org/api/child_process.html#child_process_child_process_exec_command_options_callback)) to avoid shell differences between `export X=Y` || `setenv X=Y` || `env X=Y` || `X=Y`.

### Impacted files:
```
packages/*/package.json
scripts/setup.js
packages/strapi-admin/scripts/setup.js
```

**What is the current behavior?**

When setting up a 'development' environment to contribute, then, running `npm run test` to check if everything is setup properly. I've seen that when a database connection fail for one the the test, the program get stuck into an infinite 'Database connection attempt failed!' loop.


**Steps to reproduce the problem**
Git clone project.
Setup dev environment as explained in documentation.
Setup a valid mongo database.
Don't setup postgres database.
`npm run test`


**What is the expected behavior?**
Display an error message, then, continue to run the tests on other databases.


**Suggested solutions**
I think I've identified the error, it come from `test/start.js`.

First, a promise rejection into `generate` are not properly handled. Resulting of an 'unhandled promise' error.
Then, `exec` is used to spawn the child process, but some of this child process (appCreate) spawn sub-childrens. Making the `child.kill()` not properly killing all the child process: see https://github.com/nodejs/node-v0.x-archive/issues/1811

A solution to fix this is to use `spawn` instead of `exec` with the proper options, to kill all the subchildrens (cf: https://azimi.me/2014/12/31/kill-child_process-node-js.html).

I've already made the changes on my side, can submit a PR if the bug are confirmed as impacting other people.
